STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 8, 2024
Donata MARIE Kidd
MUSKEGON COUNTY DHHS
2700 BAKER ST,
MUSKEGON HEIGHTS, MI, 49444-2157
Re: License #: CP610201318
Dear Donata MARIE Kidd:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 7, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Samantha Way, at (517) 243-9743.
Sincerely,
Melinda Gubbins, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 S. Elmwood, Ste. 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
(231) 342-3721
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation
• (8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and
make a licensing recommendation to the
department at least 15 calendar days before the
expiration date of the foster home license.
One of six foster home files reviewed did not have the renewal completed at least
15 days prior to the expiration of the license as required.
CPA Rule 400.12415 Unusual incident reporting policy
• (1) An agency must adhere to the following
incident reporting protocols:
• (a) Immediately notify the child's parents; the
department licensing authority; the lawyer
guardian ad litem and court, as applicable; the
department; and the foster child's parents, if any
of the following occurs:
• (iv) Any medical and mental illness or condition
that results in treatment at a hospital emergency
room or inpatient hospitalization of a foster child.
2

Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have incident reports completed and
submitted to licensing authority as required.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (a) Child's name.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's name prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (b) Child's date of birth.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's date of birth prior to placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (c) Available known information about the
child's health.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known health information.
3

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (d) Any known history of abuse or neglect
of the child.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known abuse/neglect history.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (e) All known emotional and psychological
factors relating to the care of the child.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known emotional and psychological factors.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (f) All known behaviors of the child.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided youth's known behaviors.
4

REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (g) Circumstances necessitating placement
or replacement of the child.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided circumstances necessitating placement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
• (1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
• (h) Any other known information to enable
the foster parent to provide a stable, safe,
and healthy environment for the foster child
and the foster family, including information
about siblings who do not reside in the
foster home as provided in federal law.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have documentation the caregiver
was provided any known information to enable foster parent to provide a safe,
stable and health environment for the foster child and the foster family including any
sibling information.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
FOM 722-08 Supervisor approval
After the caseworker routes the service plan to the
supervisor for review and approval, the supervisor must
5

approve all case service plans within 14 days of the end
of the report.
One of three independent living files reviewed did not have supervisory approval of
the case service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
8/11/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/6/2022
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate,
including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth
aged 14 and older and in the case of placement agency
foster care cases, the local DHS office designee.
Eight of eight foster care files reviewed, and three of three independent living files
reviewed did not contain all of the required signatures on the parent agency
treatment plan (PATP).
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/24/2023 INTERIM, CAP approved 9/20/2023
8/11/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 10/6/2022
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Generate and save medical passports quarterly.
• PATP signatures must include date.
• Annotate on PATP if mailed, emailed, etc.
• Licensing reports must include SOGIE and special characteristics.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• There was no consultation requested or required.
6

VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There was 1 incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. Special evaluation 2024SEC0001578 was initiated on 5/6/2024 regarding
allegations a licensed foster parent utilized corporal punishment. The licensed
foster parent was found in violation of licensing rules. The evaluation was thorough
and well written. A CAP was implemented that is still in place.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows: The
agency renewal inspection was completed on 8/24/2023 and the CAP was
approved on 9/20/2023. The agency was cited for 10 violations, 3 of which were
repeated this year. Of those 3, there was an improvement in individual incidents of
non-compliance within 2 of the violation areas (placement outline and supervisor
approval) and an increase in the number of individual incidents in 1 area (PATP).
In 2022, 8 violations were established, 2 of which were repeated this year. All of
the repeated violations remain close to the same number of individual incidents of
non-compliances. The agency will need to establish additional corrective planning
for the repeated violations to ensure a reduction of incidents.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) assessment was reviewed. The chief administrator
indicated the previous year's CAP has had a positive impact on overall agency
compliance. For the past several years the agency has included direct staff,
supervisors and program manager in development of their CAP. The chief
administrator indicated this has been helpful to ensure all staff understand the
expectations. The CA also noted the agency experienced placement disruptions
involving older youth.
Financial Overview
N/A
Staff Interviews
Interviews were conducted with two staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by the agency. Supervisors and coworkers are available to assist as
needed. Staff did not report any concerns.
7

Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care and licensing services. All files were stored securely and
there is a cross shredder for CHRI.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
____10/7/2024_______________
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
10/08/2024
